unit: Unit 9 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Slopes
title: Gas Tanks
question_text:
A study was done to examine gas tank size (in gallons) and miles driven. Twenty-nine people were randomly chosen, had their gas tanks filled, and then were asked to drive their cars until empty. The following summary data was collected:
Assuming all conditions have been verified, construct a $95\%$ confidence interval for the slope and write an interpretation of your results.

solution:
Solution

When finding a confidence interval for the slope of a regression line, the following formula should be used:

b±t∗(SEb)

...where b
is the slope of the line of best fit, t∗
is the critical value, and SEb
is the standard error of the slope.

To use this formula we need to know how to read the computer data. For a confidence interval, the T
and P
columns are ignored. Also, ignore the "constant" line. Thus, only two numbers from the table are used in this problem to construct the confidence interval.

These two values come from the "gas tank" line which is the x
variable. In this problem we have the slope value, or b
, as 11.56
and the standard error, or SEb
, as 1.769
.

Next, we need to use Table B
to find the value of the critical value or t∗
. Since our sample size is 29
, and we know that the degrees of freedom for this type of interval is n−2
, then we use a d.f. of 29−2=27
from the table. Using the 95%
confidence level column, we find a t∗
value of 2.052
.

Substituting the above values into our formula for a confidence interval we get:

11.56±(2.052)(1.769)

This simplifies to 11.56±3.63
which results in a confidence interval of (7.93,15.19)
with a unit of miles per gallon.

Finally, we need to interpret our confidence interval which will say that we are
95
%
confident that our interval captures the true slope of the regression relating our two variables.

So, Choice 'E' is correct.
